Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has shown promising applications in electrocatalytic CO2 reductions due to their high specific surface area, abundant active sites and clear structure, but the conductivity of MOFs is a great challenge. Herein, a two-dimensional (2D) coordination network materials M3(2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene)2 (M3(HHTP)2) with a good conductivity were systematically investigated and theoretical screened as promising electrocatalysts for the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reactions (CO2RR) combining density function theory (DFT) calculations and experimental validation. The theoretical calculations show that CH4 is the main reduction product for CO2RR catalyzed by Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ti3(HHTP)2. However, favorable product by Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2 and Zn3(HHTP)2 is CO. For V3(HHTP)2 and Mn3(HHTP)2, HCHO is dominant product, but the reaction of V3(HHTP)2 catalyst required a high overpotential above 1.69 V. HCOOH is primarily produced from Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2. Furthermore, the electrochemical CO2RR catalyzed by Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 were completed to validate theoretical screening. It is found that Cu3(HHTP)2 hold excellent CO2RR activity with 42.88% Faraday efficiency (FE) of CH4 with 107.92 mA cm−2 at -1.30 V vs RHE, and Ni3(HHTP)2 has 68.27% CO FE with a current density of 59.92 mA cm−2 at -0.50 V vs RHE. This work showed that theoretical screening work can provide a highly effective approach to investigate the reaction mechanism and can aid in designing novel catalysts for CO2RR, and would greatly promote design of MOF catalysts for CO2RR. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic framework Carbon dioxide electroreduction Density function theory Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Single atom catalysts (SACs), which have metal atoms scattered at the atomic level, can maximize the use of metal atoms and have shown to function exceptionally well as catalysts for a variety of reactions [1–8]. SACs have been recognized as a kind of special heterogeneous catalysts to serve as an appropriate model for the research of the structure-property relationship during reaction process because they combine the advantages of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts [9–15]. In order to reduce their surface energy, the supports of SACs always coordinate interaction to stabilize the atomically distributed metal atoms [16–20]. Therefore, both the catalytic activity and selectivity of SACs are typically greatly influenced by the local coordination environment [[21],[22]]. Although significant work has been put into expanding our knowledge, accurate control over the coordinating environment of SACs at the atomic level remains a difficult problem that has received little attention up to this point [23–28]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a group of crystalline porous materials with distinct structures and a range of compositions, not only have a wide range of potential uses, but also show significant promise as prospective starting points for the synthesis of desired materials for energy and catalysis [29–35]. Particularly, MOFs have lately been recognized as the perfect platform for the production of SACs because they allow for the rational and spatial separation of the targeted metal atoms in an atomically dispersed manner [36–40]. In contrast to conventional inorganic supports, it is easier to realize coordination environment regulation of SACs based on MOFs because of the precisely designable and tailorable structures and components in MOFs [41–45]. In addition, MOFs have other advantages over conventional catalysts: (1)The porous nature of MOFs provides a rich specific surface area for reactant adsorption; (2)The metal centers, as catalytic active sites, can be uniformly distributed on the inner and outer surfaces of the material at the atomic level; (3)The metal centers form a characteristic energy band structure by matching the electron structure of the ligand, and some of the MOFs have a certain degree of electrical conductivity, which is suitable for the absorption and transfer of electrical energy; 94) The clear crystal configuration of MOFs facilitates the study of the reaction mechanism and thus establishes the correspondence between structure and catalytic performance. However, the poor electrical conductivity of most MOFs does not facilitate the transfer of electrons [46–49], resulting in slow reaction rates for electrocatalytic CO2RR. Recently, Han's group published a paper on the reduction of CO2 by Cu SACs (Ag(S)) as a catalyst with a current density of only 1.8 mA cm−2 and a Faraday efficiency of only 78.5% for CO2 reduction at 1.0 V[50]. Schuhmann's group reported that Cu MOF (CuxOyCz) catalyzed CO2RR as a C2 product with a Faraday efficiency of 54% and a current density of 80 mA cm−2 [51]. In terms of current density, CuxOyCz is much more promising than Cu SACs (Ag(S)). However, the current density of CuxOyCz (80 mA cm−2) is not the greatest, as the current density of Cu3(HHTP)2 catalyzed CO2RR synthesized by Yaghi's group exceeds 100 mA cm−2 [53]. Therefore, its Cu3(HHTP)2 is very promising for CO2RR. M3(HHTP)2 is a type of 2D semiconductive framework that has been extensively researched for use with sensors and Li-ion batteries [[52],[53]]. Yaghi et al. originally created it by joining the Cu2+ ion with the highly conjugated linker HHTP [54]. Cu2+ ions are coupled with HHTP redox-active ligands to create 2D extended sheets, which are the building blocks of Cu3(HHTP)2 [55]. The periodic arrangement of the Cu-O4 nodes in the honeycomb-like porous structure is advantageous for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 [56]. The FE of Cu3(HHTP)2 during the electrochemical CO2 reduction test is over 65%, which, according to Yu Zhang et al.'s study, indicates that the HER process is inhibited [[54],[57]]. As a result, M3(HHTP)2 has a prospective as a CO2 reduction catalyst. In this study, the catalytic performance of 10 distinct types of M3(HHTP)2 was examined and evaluated using DFT to analyze the Gibbs free energy change profile of intermediates during the electrocatalytic reduction reaction of carbon dioxide. Calculations revealed that these novel materials are not only mechanically stable but also strongly impede rival hydrogen evolution reactions (HER). The main reduction products of Ti3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 is CH4. The main catalytic product of Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2 and Zn3(HHTP)2 is CO. For V3(HHTP)2 and Mn3(HHTP)2, HCHO is dominant product, but the reaction of V3(HHTP)2 required a high overpotential above 1.69 V. HCOOH is primarily produced from Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2. Furthermore, the experimental results manifest that the Cu3(HHTP)2 have 42.88% FE of CH4 with 107.92 mA cm−2 at −1.30 V vs RHE. Meanwhile, the main reduction product of Ni3(HHTP)2 is CO, with a Faraday efficiency of 68.27% and a current density of 59.92 mA cm−2 at −0.50 V vs RHE. Therefore, we predict that M3(HHTP)2 materials will exhibit strong catalytic activity in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, making them promising electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Stability and selectivity of theoretical calculation structures By using DFT calculations, a number of M3(HHTP)2 models with TM spanning from Sc to Zn are first checked for stability (Fig. 1 a). As seen in Fig. 1a, the calculation model was a 2 × 2 supercell of M3(HHTP)2, which contains 37 carbon atoms, 12 oxygen atoms, 12 hydrogen atoms, and three transition metal atoms. The model following optimization of the 10 different M3(HHTP)2 structures is shown in Fig. 1b, along with the distances between the O atoms and the transition metal atoms M (M = Sc to Zn). The key structural characteristics are taken into account, and it displays a stable structure. The Ti-O bond length for the Ti3(HHTP)2 site is 1.89 Å, while the Mn-O for Mn3(HHTP)2 bond length is 1.88 Å. Meanwhile, the V-O bond length is 1.86 Å, Fe-O bond length is 1.85 Å, Co-O bond length is 1.85 Å and Ni-O bond is 1.86 Å. It is obvious that they are stronger than the other M-O bonds due to the fact that shorter bond lengths are more stable. This Cr-O bond length is 1.90 Å and Cu-O is 1.94 Å at the Cr3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 sites, while the Zn-O bond length is 1.99 Å and Sc-O is 2.00 Å. It is obvious from comparing them in terms of length that Cr3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 are more capable of binding metal and oxygen than Zn3(HHTP)2 and Sc3(HHTP)2. From this angle, each of the ten catalysts (M3(HHTP)2 (M=Sc to Zn)) is a stable entity. The researched M3(HHTP)2 catalyst can be presented as structurally stable since the shorter bond length indicates that M is more closely attached to the O atom in the substrate. Fig. 1c illustrates the thermodynamic stability of M3(HHTP)2. The binding energy of M3(HHTP)2 exhibits a fairly decreasing trend from Sc to Zn, as shown by the black line in Fig. 1c, with Sc3(HHTP)2 having the lowest binding energy of -10.46 eV and Zn3(HHTP)2 having the highest binding energy of -6.04 eV (Table S2). All M3(HHTP)2 have negative binding energies, which indicates that they can all be produced steadily. In addition, as shown by the green line in Fig. 1c and Table S2, the cohesion energy of the metal atoms in M3(HHTP)2 was also estimated. It is discovered that all M3(HHTP)2 cohesion energies change in a manner resembling that of the binding energy. For all simulated M3(HHTP)2 calculations, the cohesion energy value ranges from -5.32 to -2.90 eV. It has been demonstrated that these cohesion energies are weaker than the equivalent binding energies of all computed M3(HHTP)2, indicating that the metal atoms can be evenly and persistently incorporated into the HHTP monomolecular layer, resulting in the M3(HHTP)2 monomolecular layer. In addition, the formation energies of the catalysts were examined to see whether it was possible to create M3(HHTP)2 MOF materials. The formation energy is shifting in a manner similar to this in Fig. 1c's red line. The values for all calculated M3(HHTP)2 range from -7.29 to -4.07 eV. The negative forming energy demonstrated that the formation process for all M3(HHTP)2 is exothermic. Additionally, M3(HHTP)2 is prepared for experiments more easily the more negative the formation energy is. The difference in the Gibbs free energy between the CO2RR and the HER for the initial protonation step of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction is shown in Fig. 1d. According on the position of the H atom, two distinct reaction intermediates (C*OOH and HCOO*) are produced in the first protonation step of the CO2RR. In fact, by consuming proton-electron pairs from the electrolyte solution, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), a substantial competing side reaction, may drastically reduce the Faradaic efficiency of CO2RR. These three intermediates, HCOO*, C*OOH, and H*, are thus in competition with one another. In Fig. 1d, the entire region was divided into four sections (I, II, III, and IV) by two black dashed lines. The V3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2 can be identified in the I region of -(ΔG(C*OOH)-ΔG(H*)) <0 and -(ΔG(HCOO*)-ΔG(H*)) > 0, indicating that catalysts would undergo the *+CO2 + (H ++e −) → HCOO* reaction channel (pathway 1) to generate the HCOO* intermediate. Only Co3(HHTP)2 was discovered in the IV region encompassed by -(ΔG(C*OOH)-ΔG(H*)) > 0 and -(ΔG(HCOO*)-ΔG(H*)) < 0, indicating that Co catalysts are more likely to cause pathway 2 (*+CO2+ (H ++e −) → C*OOH) intermediate C*OOH production. The fact that there are still seven catalysts (Sc3(HHTP)2, Ti3(HHTP)2, Cr3(HHTP)2, Mn3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2, Cu3(HHTP)2, and Zn3(HHTP)2) present in the II area (-(ΔG(C*OOH)-ΔG(H*)) > 0, and -(ΔG(HCOO*)-ΔG(H*)) > 0), suggests that these catalysts are totally able to inhibit the HER. Additionally, a red diagonal line divides II into two pieces. the catalyst on the left side of the red diagonal line is more likely to go through the pathway 1 reaction, creating the HCOO* intermediate;whereas the catalyst on the right side is more likely to go through the pathway 2 reaction, creating the C*OOH intermediate, by the reaction of *+CO2+ (H ++e −) → C*OOH. Fig. 1d makes it quite evident that the majority of catalysts can impede the HER. Seven M3(HHTP)2 materials (M=Sc, Ti, Ni, Cr, Mn, Cu, and Zn) were discovered with good ability for inhibiting HER based on the explanation in Fig. 1d above, indicating they may have satisfied activity for CO2RR. 2.2 The mechanism of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction Due to M3(HHTP)2′s unusual monolayer structure, which keeps adjacent metal atoms apart, it is challenging to produce multi-carbon products by carbon-carbon coupling reactions. As a result, the creation of C1 products will be the exclusive emphasis of this paper. The potential reaction pathways to generate C1 products for CO2RR catalyzed by M3(HHTP)2 were depicted in Fig. 2 . Fig. S2 depicts the intermediates in CO2RR process. The favorable reaction path and catalytic products for each of ten distinct catalytic M3(HHTP)2 are explored. The overpotentials, the Gibbs free energy changes for the reaction, and the adsorption energies of reactants and products, was analyzed and discussed. As shown in Fig. 2, CO2 can reach to either the C*OOH intermediate (Pathway 2) or the HCOO* intermediate (pathway 1) during the first protonation step. In Pathway 1 and 2, the intermediates C*OOH and HCOO* were constantly protonated to generate C*O and HCOO*H, respectively. The adsorption energies of various intermediates on M3(HHTP)2 were displayed in Table S3. According to Table S3, the CO, HCOOH, and HCHO adsorption energies on Cu and Ti centers vary from −0.57 to −1.62 eV, showing that these C1 intermediates are difficult to desorb from the reaction centers on catalyst. These intermediates will keep on being converted to CH4. However, because CO, HCOOH, or HCHO have binding energies that are greater than −0.33 eV on the other eight metal centers, it is likely that these 2e or 4e reduction intermediates will quickly desorb as products from the catalyst. Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ti3(HHTP)2 were therefore focused on the 8e reduction of CO2 to CH4 (Fig. 3 i and j), while only 2e (Fig. 3a–f) or 4e (Fig. 3g and h) reduction processes were taken into account when calculating the Gibbs free energy profiles for the other eight M3(HHTP)2 materials. According to Fig. 3a–d, the first hydrogenation of CO2 prioritizes the formation of C*OOH due to low overpotential for Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2, and Zn3(HHTP)2, therefore proceed via pathway 2 to produce the C*O as intermediation. According to Table S3, the adsorption energies of CO on Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2, and Zn3(HHTP)2 is in the range from -0.360 (Zn3(HHTP)2) to -0.06 (Ni3(HHTP)2) eV, indicating that CO can easily detach from the surface of the catalysts. Hence, the reduction products of Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2, and Zn3(HHTP)2 are mainly CO. However, the first hydrogenation of CO2 to generate HCOO* has a smaller overpotential than that to form C*OOH for Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2 (Fig. 3e–f), which results in the intermediated HCOOH through pathway 1. Since the adsorption energy of HCOOH on Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2 is -0.13 and 0.10 eV (lower than for CO), therefor primary reduction products of CO2 on Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2 are mainly HCOOH. Because CO and HCOOH have greater adsorption energies for V3(HHTP)2, Mn3(HHTP)2, Ti3(HHTP)2, and Cu3(HHTP)2 (Fig. 3g–j), the two intermediates can continue to be reduced. The adsorbed C*O would be protonated continuously via the reactions C*O → C*HO or C*O → C*OH. And the adsorbed HCOO*H can follow by the reactions HCOO*H → C*HO or HCOO*H → O*CH. The favorable reaction route was determined by the Gibbs free energy change of the reaction, is depicted in Fig. 3g–j. According to these figures, the values of G(C*HO) in the third protonation step are lower than those of G(C*OH) and G(O*CH) for all four catalysts, therefore The reaction pathway C*HO → O*CH2 → HCHO is dominated in reaction process. Because adsorption energy of HCHO on V3(HHTP)2 and Mn3(HHTP)2 is sufficiently low (-0.642 and -0.328 eV, respectively) (Table S3), it can readily be removed from the surface of catalysts as products. The adsorption energies of HCHO on Ti3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2, however, are -0.93 and -1.01 eV, respectively, indicating that it may be diffcult to remove HCHO from catalysts surfaces. As a result, the adsorbed HCHO can constantly reduce reaction on Ti3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2. Next, there are two reaction pathways were studied depending on the succeeding hydrogenation sites. On one hand, O*CH2 → CH2O*H → CH3O*H → * + CH3OH can occur if H is added to the O atom. On the other hand, if H is added to a C atom, it can proceed through the steps O*CH2 → O*CH3 → CH3O*H → * + CH3OH to produce CH3OH or O*CH2 → O*CH3 → O* + CH4 to produce CH4. Because large adsorption energy of CH3OH is -1.30 and -0.77 eV on Ti3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2, respectively (Table S3), CH3OH is very difficult to desorb and will be constantly reduced as an intermediate. From Fig. 3i and j, O*CH2 → CH2O*H → CH3O*H → O*H + CH4 is the ideal reaction pathway for Ti3(HHTP)2, as the Gibbs free energy change of CH2O*H is smaller than that of O*CH3. Similar to this, for Cu3(HHTP)2, CH2O*H has a lower Gibbs free energy change than O*CH3, but CH3O*H → O*H + CH4 has a positive Gibbs free energy change with well beyond 2 eV. Therefore, O*CH2 → O*CH3 → O* + CH4 is the preferred reaction route rather than O*CH2 → CH2O*H → CH3O*H → O*H + CH4 for Cu3(HHTP)2. According to the discussion above, CH4 was the main products both for Ti3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 catalysts. The overpotential is a key factor in the evaluation of catalytic performance. The smaller the overpotential, the better the catalytic performance. For the entire catalytic reduction reaction, the potential-determining step (PDS) was identified as the maximum free energy step, and the equation η=Ueq-Uonset was used to determine the overpotential of the reaction [58–60]. Table 1 summary the PDS, limiting potential (UL), and overpotential (η) for the 10 different catalysts. From Table 1, the overpotentials (Sc3(HHTP)2, Cr3(HHTP)2, Fe3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2, and Zn3(HHTP)2) for the 2e products CO and HCOOH range from 0.02 for Zn3(HHTP)2 to 0.88 V; for the four-electron product HCHO, the low one is Mn3(HHTP)2 (0.87 V) and the high one is V3(HHTP)2 (1.69 V); for 8e product CH4, overpotential is 1.37 V for Cu3(HHTP)2 and 1.38 V for Ti3(HHTP)2 respectively, suggesting that Cu3(HHTP)2 has more activity because its overpotential is lower than that of Ti3(HHTP)2. Our theoretical results predict that all these catalysts would have promising catalytic ability for electrocatalytic CO2RR. 2.3 Synthesis and structural characterizations Two two-dimensional cellular semiconductors MOFs, M3(HHTP)2 (M=Ni, Cu) were attainted by hydrothermal synthesis [61] . Then in order to prove successful synthesis, various methods were used to characterize these two M3(HHTP)2 materials. The morphology of M3(HHTP)2 was confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Cu3(HHTP)2 has a uniform hexagonal prismatic rod shape, while Ni3(HHTP)2 has a coral-like morphology, according to SEM photographs (Figs. S3, S4). The void fraction of Cu3(HHTP)2 was determined by N2 adsorption analysis at 77k, showing i-type isotherms, a characteristic of materials with tiny pores. And the Cu3(HHTP)2 material has a surface area of 350 m2g−1 according to Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). The high specific surface area of the Cu3(HHTP)2 catalyst boosts the reaction's catalytic selectivity and makes CO2RR more efficient. The crystallinity of M3(HHTP)2 was determined by using powder x-ray diffraction (PXRD). The lattice faces of (100), (200), (210), (310), and (201) correspond to the Cu3(HHTP)2 diffraction peak positions of 4.7°, 9.5°, 12.7°, 16.3°, and 27.6° at 2θ. (Fig. S3). The lattice faces of (100), (200), (210), (211), and (111) represent the Ni3(HHTP)2 diffraction peak positions of 4.6°, 9.5°, 12.6°, 16.5°, and 28.3° at 2θ. (Fig. S4). In the XPS spectra of Cu3(HHTP)2, Cu2+2p1/2 and 2p3/2 are revealed to exhibit peaks at 954.7 and 934.9 eV, respectively (Fig. 4 a). To get more insight into center metal, XPS character was completed, showed in Fig. 4. There are two peaks 954.7 and 934.9 eV in the XPS spectrum of Cu3(HHTP)2 (Fig. 4a), belonging to Cu2+2p1/2 and 2p3/2 respectively. The other two peaks at 952.2 and 932.6 eV correspond to Cu+2p1/2 and 2p3/2¸respectively. It is interesting to note that the peak at 942.2 eV could be the result of charge transfer between metal center and coordinate. In Fig. 2b, the main typical peaks at 874.1 eV (Ni2+ 2p1/2) and 856.2 eV (Ni2+ 2p3/2) further demonstrate the presence of Ni2+ in Ni3(HHTP)2. PXRD and XPS results are well agreement with previous reports, indicating Ni3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 was synthesized successfully. 2.4 CO2RR performance evaluation The as-synthesized M3(HHTP)2 (M=Ni, Cu) materials were used as electrocatalysts for CO2RR. Firstly, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves for electrocatalysts was examined and illustrated in Figure 5(a). The LSV curve showed that the current density of Ni3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 catalysts are both significantly higher in CO2 gas than that in Ar gas showing that the two catalysts are catalytically active for CO2RR. The performance of the Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 for CO2RR were evaluated in a typical H-type liquid cell with the catalysts drop-cast on flat glassy-carbon electrodes. The gaseous products were identified by on-line gas chromatography, and liquid products were detected by 1HNMR. The results showed that the main gaseous products are CH4, CO, H2 and a small amount of C2H4 for Cu3(HHTP)2, and CO, H2 and small amount of CH4 for Ni3(HHTP)2, respectively. No liquid products were observed for these two catalysts. The Faraday efficiency (FEs) and current density for Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 at various potentials are shown in Fig. 5 b and c, respectively. Before -1.30 V, the hydrogen evolution reaction was decreased, while the FEs of CO2 to CH4 is significantly enhanced with increasing potentials. The FEs of CO2 to CH4 is highest at -1.30 VRHE, reaching 42.88% with the current density of 107.92 mA cm−2 and the bias current density for CH4 of 46.28 mA cm−2. The FEs of CH4 was decreased, as potentials from -1.30 V to 1.70 V. For Ni3(HHTP)2, the highest FEs of 68.27% was achieved at potentials of -0.5VRHE with the current density of 59.92 mA cm−2 and the bias current density of 40.91 mA cm−2 for CO. The high catalytic ability of the Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 for CO2RR are consistent with above DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 5d and e, the Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 catalyst were run continuously for 12000s at -1.30 VRHE without significant current decay both for FECH4 and current density. This means that the Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 have excellent stability for CO2RR. This remarkable stability may be due to the metal center forming a strong coupling with the surrounding oxygen atomic ligands, and thus maintaining the atomic dispersion of the metal sites. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy in Fig. 5f showed that the Cu3(HHTP)2 catalyst has a lower resistance than Ni3(HHTP)2 as well as a faster electron kinetics, which is consist with the LSV results. The M3(HHTP)2 (M=Ni, Cu) materials were employed as electrocatalysts for CO2RR in their as-synthesised form. Fig. 5(a) shows an analysis of the linear sweep Voltammetry (LSV) curves for electrocatalysts. The LSV curve for Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 revealed that when CO2 gas is supplied, the current density of the Ni3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 catalysts is much higher than that of Ar gas in the same condition. In contrast to Ar, On the basis of this, it is demonstrated that the catalysts Ni3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 are catalytically active for CO2RR. With the catalysts drop-cast on flat glassy-carbon electrodes, the performance of the Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 catalysts for CO2RR was assessed in a typical H-type liquid cell. Online gas chromatography was used to identify the gaseous byproducts, while 1HNMR was used to find the liquid byproducts. According to the findings, the primary gaseous products for Cu3(HHTP)2 are CH4, CO, H2, and a negligible quantity of C2H4, and for Ni3(HHTP)2, it is CO, H2, and a negligible amount of CH4. For these two catalysts, no liquid products were found. 2.5 Theoretical insights To further investigate the active site of the M3(HHTP)2 (M=Cu, Ni) catalysts, the charge density difference of M3(HHTP)2 was calculated using DFT as well. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), Charge density difference both for Ni3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 underwent rearrangement and mainly focused on the metal and O atoms, which means that a strong chemical bond was formed between the two kinds of atoms. Comparing with Ni3(HHTP)2, charge density difference of Cu3(HHTP)2 are more focused on metal, suggesting Cu center has strong active ability to CO2. In addition, the projected density of states (PDOS) of Ni3(HHTP)2 and Cu3(HHTP)2 showed in Fig. 6(b) indicates the 3d orbital of Metal atom was strongly hybridized with the 2p orbital of the O atom, showing strong interaction between the M atom and the O atom as well. The electron localization function (ELF) was used to conduct additional analysis of the electron distribution at the active site. Fig. 6(c) reveals that both Cu-O and Ni-O are obviously coordination bonds character, where electrons are transferred from the O to the Cu, Ni atoms, which is consistent with the charge density difference analysis. This kind if structure allows the formation of stable low-energy transition states, as well as easy desorption of CO and CH4, to better facilitate electrochemical CO2RR. 3 Conclusions By theoretical screening approach and experiment, ten different M3(HHTP)2 (Sc to Zn) MOFs were evaluated for the catalytic activity of CO2RR. According to calculations, all ten catalysts have good electrochemical performance of CO2RR, while the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) can be well suppressed. The primary reduction product for Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ti3(HHTP)2 is CH4, but the favorable product for Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2 and Zn3(HHTP)2 is CO, and for V3(HHTP)2 and Mn3(HHTP)2, HCHO is dominant product, but the reaction of V3(HHTP)2 catalyst required a high overpotential above 1.69 V. HCOOH is primarily produced from Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2. According to the experimental findings, Cu3(HHTP)2 has 42.88% FE of CH4 at 107.92 mA cm−2 at −1.30 V vs. RHE. Ni3(HHTP)2 also produces CO as its primary reduction product, which has a Faraday efficiency of 68.27% and a current density of 59.92 mA cm−2 at −0.50 V vs. RHE. The Experiments and DFT calculations both indicate that M3(HHTP)2 is promising catalysts for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has shown promising applications in electrocatalytic CO2 reductions due to their high specific surface area, abundant active sites and clear structure, but the conductivity of MOFs is a great challenge. Herein, a two-dimensional (2D) coordination network materials M3(2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene)2 (M3(HHTP)2) with a good conductivity were systematically investigated and theoretical screened as promising electrocatalysts for the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reactions (CO2RR) combining density function theory (DFT) calculations and experimental validation. The theoretical calculations show that CH4 is the main reduction product for CO2RR catalyzed by Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ti3(HHTP)2. However, favorable product by Sc3(HHTP)2, Co3(HHTP)2, Ni3(HHTP)2 and Zn3(HHTP)2 is CO. For V3(HHTP)2 and Mn3(HHTP)2, HCHO is dominant product, but the reaction of V3(HHTP)2 catalyst required a high overpotential above 1.69 V. HCOOH is primarily produced from Cr3(HHTP)2 and Fe3(HHTP)2. Furthermore, the electrochemical CO2RR catalyzed by Cu3(HHTP)2 and Ni3(HHTP)2 were completed to validate theoretical screening. It is found that Cu3(HHTP)2 hold excellent CO2RR activity with 42.88% Faraday efficiency (FE) of CH4 with 107.92 mA cm−2 at -1.30 V vs RHE, and Ni3(HHTP)2 has 68.27% CO FE with a current density of 59.92 mA cm−2 at -0.50 V vs RHE. This work showed that theoretical screening work can provide a highly effective approach to investigate the reaction mechanism and can aid in designing novel catalysts for CO2RR, and would greatly promote design of MOF catalysts for CO2RR.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical Screening and experimental validation of M3(2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene)2 for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction
